The 'utility cover', also known as the 'utility cap' and 'eight-pointed cover',
is the United States Marine Corps cap, worn with their utility uniform. It is an
eight-pointed hat, with a visor similar to a baseball
cap. [http://www.marineparents.com/marinecorps/uniforms.asp Uniforms of the
Marine Corps from MarineParents.com: A Place to Connect & Share(tm) ] It is worn "blocked", that is, creased and peaked,
for a sharper appearance. [http://www.usmc.mil/almars/almar2000.nsf/52f4f5d-
11f10b4c4852569b8006a3e35/2c62f1e9d178aad785256a55005e1473?OpenDocument Marine
Corps ALMAR ->MCBUL 1020. MARINE CORPS UNIFORM BOARD MEETING NR 190 AND 191 ][http://www.hqmc.net/index.php?Itemid=29&id=47&option=com_content&-
task=view Marine For Life - Marine Corps Uniforms ] It is also worn by the U.S. Navy units such as Seabees and
Beachmasters. It is also worn with the newer Navy Working
Uniform [http://www.news.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=22519 New Navy
Working Uniform and Service Uniform Concepts Approved ] as well as the Woodland CUU and desert DCU uniform. It is also under
consideration by the United States Coast Guard's uniform board, and has been
publicly wear-tested by Commandant ADM Robert J. Papp, Jr..
categories: Military equipment of the United States
